notes.text: The use with a preceding adverb, e.g., physically challenged, originally intended to give a more positive tone than such terms as disabled or handicapped, arose in the US in the 1980s. Despite the originally serious intention, the term rapidly became stalled by uses whose intention was to make fun of the attempts at euphemism and whose tone was usually clearly ironic: examples include cerebrally challenged (not very smart), follicularly challenged (bald or balding), vertically challenged (short), etc.

definitions: (used euphemistically) impaired or disabled in a specified respect
shortDefinitions: used euphemistically to indicate that someone suffers disability in specified respect

definitions: lacking or deficient in a specified respect
shortDefinitions: used to indicate that person or thing is lacking or deficient in specified respect
